features.text: # ENERGY PRESENT AND FUTURE IN EU AND AUSTRIA

features.text: Against a backdrop of increasing energy requirements and a growing awareness of the environmental impact of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, energy is at the heart of the climate challenge and the use of renewable energy is driven to new records. The European union has made a firm commitment to drive Europe’s transition to net zero and accelerate the take-up of renewables to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

features.__generatedText__: Against a backdrop of increasing energy requirements and a growing awareness of the environmental impact of greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, energy is at the heart of the climate challenge and the use of renewable energy is driven to new records. The European union has made a firm commitment to drive Europe’s transition to net zero and accelerate the take-up of renewables to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

features.text: The energy sector in Europe accounts for over 70% of total greenhouse gas emissions. The contribution of the energy sector to emissions has been quite stable in the last 15 years, with a visible little deflection in 2019 associated to the Covid-19 lockdowns. A transition to renewable energy production is a key element of the economy decarbonisation which requires a massive transformation in the way energy provided, transported, and used. Earth observation can provide comprehensive, accurate and actionable information to support decision making for the decarbonisation process.

features.__generatedText__:
The energy sector in Europe accounts for over 70% of total greenhouse gas emissions. The contribution of the energy sector to emissions has been quite stable in the last 15 years, with a visible little deflection in 2019 associated to the Covid-19 lockdowns.

A transition to renewable energy production is a key element of the economy decarbonisation which requires a massive transformation in the way energy provided, transported, and used. Earth observation can provide comprehensive, accurate and actionable information to support decision making for the decarbonisation process.

features.text: While the share of renewables in the overall energy mix has been steadily growing in the last 15 years - reaching 22% of gross energy consumption in 2020 - EU countries have set challenging targets towards the 2050 carbon neutrality and the 2030 interim 55% global GHG reduction goals. In order to achieve those targets, each country has put in place [National Energy and Climate Plans](https://ec.europa.eu/info/energy-climate-change-environment/implementation-eu-countries/energy-and-climate-governance-and-reporting/national-energy-and-climate-plans_en) that define specific strategies and targets for each domain of intervention. In particular, the European Commission’s current goal for renewable energies is to achieve at least a 32% share in the energy mix across Europe by 2030. The [Renewable Energy directive](https://energy.ec.europa.eu/topics/renewable-energy/renewable-energy-directive-targets-and-rules/renewable-energy-directive_en) sets the common target for the amount of renewable energy in the EU’s energy consumption. The proposed revision suggests [further evolution of the 32% target](https://energy.ec.europa.eu/topics/renewable-energy/renewable-energy-directive-targets-and-rules/renewable-energy-targets_en) to accelerate the take-up of renewables in the EU.

features.text:
The transition away from fossil energy sources is a daunting task for economies that have developed based on fossil energy sources, and the growth of renewable energy sources production should be carefully planned to make sure that planning of their deployment is optimised.

Information derived from Earth Observation can be a precious support tool to streamline activities in the renewable energy sector: from planning and development - energy potential hindcasting, siting, EIA, plant design, electrification - to operations and maintenance - energy yield nowcasting and forecasting, operations planning and monitoring.

features.text:
## Planning and development
EO satellites track relevant parameters for on-shore renewables,  such as wind patterns, cloud cover and solar irradiance (as in this
animation). They track the metocean suite of variables (wind, wave and climate) for off-shore wind farms. And storage potential in hydro reservoirs can be monitored as well.

Planning and development

EO satellites track relevant parameters for on-shore renewables, such as wind patterns, cloud cover and solar irradiance (as in this animation). They track the metocean suite of variables (wind, wave and climate) for off-shore wind farms. And storage potential in hydro reservoirs can be monitored as well.

features.text:
## Operations and maintenance:
EO satellites can support management and mitigation of environmental issues associated with large infrastructure investment projects, e.g. measuring environmental changes due to encroachment of human activity around hydropower reservoirs.
They can also play an important role in monitoring and maintaining the infrastructure, e.g. by checking hydropower dam
stability using PS-InSAR, or monitoring leakage along pipelines when it comes to other, existing energy infrastructure.
The image on the right shows, for instance, the [Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline leak](https://www.esa.int/Applications/Observing_the_Earth/Satellites_detect_methane_plume_in_Nord_Stream_leak) which occurred during the first week of October 2022.

features.text:
## The Austrian energy scenario While Austria is a virtuous country when it comes to renewable energy, with a share well above EU average for the last 20 years (or more), it has set ambitious goals towards 2030 within its National Energy and Climate Plan, with a planned share of renewables between 45% and 50% of gross final energy consumption (with a striking ambition of 100% of electricity produced from renewables). The current Austrian scenario sees a predominant role of hydropower, overriding by three times the total of all other renewable sources (EUROSTAT statistics). Wind is the second source by importance, surpassing solid biofuels since 2004. Nonetheless, current wind energy production is restricted to a very limited geographic area. How can GTIF play a role in this energy scenario? GTIF provides various EXPLORE TOOLS for you to investigate the challenges and opportunities in the energy transition. The Wind Energy site suitability assessment & trade-off tool lets you explore the geographic distribution of the wind energy potential throughout the country. Intuitive sliders let you constrain this information by other parameters, such as elevation, slope, distance to settlements, distance to the energy grid and presence of protected areas in order to identify the best potential installation areas. Thanks to a large variety of base maps it’s then possible to look at additional trade-offs, like underlying land cover or soil quality. Based on the analyses, best zones can be exported and reports summarizing your analysis can be generated.
The Solar Energy site suitability assessment & trade-off tool shows solar irradiance, the amount of yearly solar energy, over the country. This is an indicator of the electricity that can be generated by a solar cell module in a specific location. As for the wind energy tool, you can filter the solar irradiance map according to the value of other parameters in the area (elevation, slope, aspect, distance to the energy grid and presence of protected areas) to identify the most suitable locations for new solar installations, and further look into trade-offs bases on land cover and soil quality.

features.text:
## Wind Energy site suitability assessment & trade-off tool
The mean wind power density is a measure of available wind resource at any location. The GTIF wind Energy site suitability assessment tool shows that areas of high wind power density are primarily located in the southern and western regions of the country.
